You will have plenty of time for them when you come back from your travels. We must first see you well established in your profession, and then you will have leisure to make acquaintances, and form connections, that will be of use to you in your future life. I do not mean, however, to find fault with your plan of travelling; it is a very good one, and I daresay you will see a great deal that will be of service to you. But you must not think of going abroad immediately; you must first get a good understanding of your profession, and then you will be able to travel with more advantage. And, besides, you must not think of going abroad without a proper introduction; you must have letters of recommendation, and you must know the people you are going to visit. en_results_raw: ease, since it will be frequently called into action. But there is a meanness in all the arts which ladies sometimes condescend to employ to captivate. Whatever bears affinity to cunning is despicable. I have been so shocked by some of the artifices of the female sex, that I have often wondered how they can be so sanguine as to expect that their artifices will succeed. But I suppose it is the natural result of their education. They are taught to please, and to please by any means; and when they have acquired the art of pleasing, they are not very scrupulous as to the means by which they do it. But I must say, that I have never been able to understand why a woman should be so very anxious to please, when she has already secured the heart of the man she wishes to please. It seems to me, that if she has gained his affection, she should be content to rest on that, and not be so very anxious to secure it by every art and every means in her power.

en_results_raw: he is a very different man from what he is to the less prosperous. His pride does not repulse where he would be admired, and his cold reserve is not unpleasant where he wishes to please. In his behaviour to Elizabeth, there was a constant, though unobtrusive, attention, which she could not but perceive, and which was exactly in harmony with her own feelings. She was pleased by his attention, and yet she could not help but feel a little intimidated by his grandeur. As they walked together, she found herself stealing glances at him, trying to read his thoughts, but his expression remained inscrutable. The other guests at the ball seemed to fade into the background as they conversed, their words flowing easily, like a gentle stream meandering through the countryside. It was as if they were the only two people in the room, lost in their own little world of thoughts and feelings. And yet, despite the sense of connection that was growing between them, Elizabeth could not shake off the feeling that Mr. Darcy was hiding something behind his polite smile and courteous manner.

I must confess, however, that I find it very difficult to attend to the music, when I am playing, and at the same time to think of the expression and feeling which I wish to convey. It seems to me that the two things are incompatible, and that one must either play with attention to the music, or with attention to the expression, but not with both at the same time. I daresay, however, that this is only a difficulty which I shall overcome with practice, and that in time I shall be able to play with both attention to the music and attention to the expression.

en_results_raw: But if he means to be there half his time or more, and is not to be deterred by the neighbourhood, he may like the house so well as to be tempted to stay longer than he originally intended, and so end by making the place his principal residence. It is not to be supposed that his sisters will have any great amount of pleasure in seeing their brother so frequently at home, but they will probably be glad to have him in the neighbourhood, and to be able to see him occasionally. As for Mr. Bennet, he will probably be glad to have his son so near him, and to be able to see him frequently, and he will probably be pleased to have the neighbourhood enlivened by the presence of a young man of Mr. Bingley's fortune and standing. But Mrs. Bennet's feelings on the subject are likely to be very different; she will probably be delighted to have her daughter married to a man of such great fortune and standing, and she will probably be eager to have the marriage take place as soon as possible, in order that she may have the pleasure of seeing her daughter established in a home of her own, and of being able to visit her frequently.

The love of gardening is a very common passion, and one that is perfectly legitimate, for it is a taste that is founded on the love of nature, and the pleasure of cultivating and improving the beauty of the earth. It is a pursuit that is not only delightful in itself, but also productive of great benefits, for it promotes health, and provides a pleasant and innocent recreation. Many people find great satisfaction in planning and laying out their gardens, and in selecting the plants and flowers that they will cultivate, and there is a great deal of pleasure to be derived from watching the progress of their growth, and from enjoying the beauty and fragrance of the blossoms. The pleasure of gardening is not limited to the wealthy, for even the humblest cottage can have its garden, and the simplest flowers can bring joy and delight to those who cultivate them.

El poder también puede ser un medio para lograr otros placeres y satisfacciones, como la riqueza, el estatus social o la admiración de los demás. Sin embargo, es importante destacar que el poder en sí mismo no es necesariamente un fin en sí mismo, sino más bien un medio para lograr otros objetivos y deseos. She was particularly struck by one passage, in which her aunt cautioned her against the dangers of being too proud, and of not being sufficiently mindful of the feelings of others. Elizabeth felt that this was a fault of which she was herself guilty, and she made a mental resolution to be more careful in future. He then turned away, and began to converse with Colonel Fitzwilliam, who had been watching the scene with great amusement. "Well, Darcy," said the Colonel, with a laugh, "you seem to have got into a scrape. What is the meaning of all this?" Mr. Darcy shrugged his shoulders, and replied, "I have no idea, but I suppose it is some new scheme of my aunt's to throw me in the way of some eligible young lady." The Colonel chuckled, and said, "Well, I think you are quite right, but I must say, I rather admire your coolness under fire. You are a true soldier, Darcy." Mr. Darcy smiled slightly, and replied, "I have had a great deal of practice, my dear Colonel, in learning to keep my temper under control." Just then, the lady who had been the cause of the disturbance, approached them, and said, "Mr. Darcy, I must apologize for my behavior earlier. I was quite carried away, and I fear I may have said some things that I should not have said." Mr. Darcy bowed, and replied, "You are too kind, madam. I assure you, I have forgotten all about it." The lady smiled, and said, "I am glad to hear it, sir. I must say, I am rather surprised at your forbearance. Most men would have been furious at such treatment." Mr. Darcy smiled again, and replied, "I am not most men, madam. I am a man of great self-control, and I never allow myself to be ruffled by the whims of others." The lady laughed, and said, "I think you are a very unusual man, Mr. Darcy. I am glad to have made your acquaintance." Mr. Darcy bowed, and replied, "The pleasure is mine, madam. I hope we shall meet again soon." And with that, the lady turned and walked away, leaving Mr. Darcy and the Colonel to their conversation.

en_results_raw: it, nor did the evening wear away with much apparent rapidity. The ladies retired to the drawing-room, and the gentlemen to the library, as was their usual custom; but as the night advanced, the conversation in the latter apartment grew more and more languid, and the pauses between the remarks of the gentlemen became longer and more frequent. The ladies, too, found it difficult to keep up a conversation, and the silence in the drawing-room was only broken by the ticking of the clock and the occasional rustling of a dress. It was evident that every one was thinking of the same subject, and that the suspense was becoming almost unbearable. At length, the gentlemen joined the ladies, and the whole party sat down to a late supper, which was eaten in almost complete silence. The only sound was the clinking of glasses and the occasional cough of one of the gentlemen. The ladies looked pale and anxious, and the gentlemen's faces were grave and thoughtful. It was clear that the night would be a sleepless one for all of them.

en_results: of saying, and his wife had no difficulty in maintaining her usual flow of conversation, though it was now more than ever her wish to say
en_results_raw: of saying, and his wife had no difficulty in maintaining her usual flow of conversation, though it was now more than ever her wish to say nothing that might be in the least degree interesting to her husband. She had no fear of his being displeased, for she knew that he would not be so, but she was anxious to avoid any subject that might lead to a discussion, and so she rattled on about the weather, and the news of the neighbourhood, and the health of their friends, without once touching on the subject that was uppermost in her mind. Mr. Bennet listened to her with his usual air of quiet amusement, and made the occasional remark that was necessary to keep the conversation going, but he said nothing that could be construed into a desire to know more about his daughter's engagement, or to offer any opinion on the subject. His wife was relieved that he did not seem disposed to make any objection, but she could not help feeling a little anxious about his silence, and she wondered what he might be thinking, and whether he would eventually express some disapproval of the match.

"What an excellent father Mr. Darcy must have been," was her remark to Elizabeth when the latter first spoke of him. "You know of course that he was a most proud and disagreeable man, and I hope you will not let his son be too much elated by his grandeur." Elizabeth smiled and said, "I am not afraid of Mr. Darcy; besides, I have no reason to expect that he will make any particular interest in me, or that I shall see much of him." "Oh, you are quite wrong, my dear," replied her mother; "he will be delighted to see you, and will make great friends with you; and you will be a great favourite with him, I am sure. He is a very agreeable young man, and I daresay he will be very much pleased with you." Elizabeth made no answer, and her mother went on. "I do hope, Lizzy, that you will not refuse him if he should ask you to dance. You know it is a partner that he cannot well refuse, and it will be a great thing for you to be so distinguished." Elizabeth coloured at the idea, but her mother did not perceive it, and continued, "I do not think Mr. Darcy will be so very proud, but still he is a very rich young man, and will have a great estate, and therefore you ought to be very much pleased." Elizabeth was not very much pleased, but she did not say so, and her mother went on talking of Mr. Darcy and his estate, and of the great things he would do for his sisters, and of the great respectability of his family, and of the great advantage it would be to her to be so connected with them.
